channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Every July 1, former Major League slugger Bobby Bonilla gets $1.2 million from the New York Mets, a team he hasn’t played for in over 20 years. It's either one of the worst deals in sports history or the most brilliant retirement plan by an athlete ever. https://t.co/RuUywMUSZ8

President Biden selected more than a dozen people to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the country’s highest civilian honor, including Simone Biles, Steve Jobs, Denzel Washington and John McCain https://t.co/33LHbF8F08
Inflation-protected U.S. savings bonds are yielding an eye-popping 9.62%—if you can fight through the red tape to actually buy one https://t.co/05yNwzyWMu
Ukrainian officers say recently supplied U.S. guided-rocket systems are strengthening their hand against Russian forces https://t.co/qWKeE5BRt8
Apple released the first-ever iPhone in the U.S. on June 29, 2007. Here’s a look back at every iteration. https://t.co/ApIj80xVLM
The woman alleged to be at the heart of one of the world’s biggest cryptocurrency frauds is now on the FBI’s 10 Most Wanted Fugitives list, according to the agency https://t.co/eesj7KWjY8
From @WSJopinion: Cassidy Hutchinson showed more guts than any of Trump’s men. Her testimony strengthens the case for prosecution, writes @Peggynoonannyc. https://t.co/YReDiztMoq
WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has appealed his extradition from the U.K., prolonging legal wrangling over whether he should be sent to the U.S. to face spying charges https://t.co/oqWEIu4fZq

A former top corporate lawyer for Apple pleaded guilty to insider trading, admitting he used access to the company’s undisclosed earnings results to reap hundreds of thousands of dollars in illicit gains, prosecutors said https://t.co/oNvnb1jVcs
After nine days, Elon Musk is on his longest stretch without posting on Twitter in nearly five years https://t.co/JCgdUbUsCn
New Zealand designated far-right group the Proud Boys as a terrorist organization, highlighting the role that the group played in last year’s attack on the U.S. Capitol https://t.co/eRX7xGxTNJ

President Biden said he supports changing Senate filibuster rules, which would allow legislation protecting abortion access to pass the chamber with 51 votes rather than 60. Here's what you need to know. https://t.co/ZcIadxKhjG
Air New Zealand plans to introduce pods with flat beds in economy class, initially installing them on direct flights to Chicago and New York from Auckland https://t.co/K7Ow8oxaF0
SpaceX has been given permission to operate its satellite-internet service Starlink on everything from airplanes and boats to RVs https://t.co/1Q3QxF4ZPo
After nine days, Elon Musk is on his longest stretch without posting on Twitter in nearly five years https://t.co/GnTA2N9Xcc
The woman alleged to be at the heart of one of the world’s biggest cryptocurrency frauds is now on the FBI’s 10 Most Wanted Fugitives list, according to the agency https://t.co/u2gYtg6jCK
The U.S. and key allies across Europe and Asia are closing ranks against China, with Beijing seen as a shared security challenge, more troubling for its backing of Russia https://t.co/aBmFyew0RZ
Stocks closed out their worst first half of a year since 1970. Investors are bracing for more volatility ahead. https://t.co/inBeJ4cpvY
The superstar golfers who have joined LIV Golf, like Bryson DeChambeau and Brooks Koepka, have something in common. They hadn’t been playing well. https://t.co/SPHsGp5HIt

Ketanji Brown Jackson became the 116th associate justice and the first Black woman on the U.S. Supreme Court, after Chief Justice John Roberts and retiring Justice Stephen Breyer administered oaths of office https://t.co/KNmtbhtFek

From @WSJopinion: Student debt forgiveness is a political bribe. Buying votes is the only possible justification for such an unfair giveaway of taxpayer money, write Phil Gramm and Mike Solon. https://t.co/W0fwGbip3l

The Supreme Court ruled that the Biden administration can end the Trump-era “Remain in Mexico” policy, which required either jailing asylum applicants from Central America or denying them entry to the U.S. until their cases are resolved (corrects link) https://t.co/x1EwwVXP8E

Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Hong Kong for the 25th anniversary of its handover from Britain, two years after Beijing imposed a national-security law that has crushed dissent in the city https://t.co/CiKPbzNEL9
The Supreme Court limited the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to regulate greenhouse-gas emissions. The ruling curbs the regulatory power of federal agencies https://t.co/WwPiMuGOIz
Breaking: President Biden said he supports suspending the filibuster, if necessary, to codify Roe v. Wade into law https://t.co/fHDLbs6x2z

Cassidy Hutchinson has faced a wave of online attacks from Trump’s supporters following her testimony before the Jan. 6 committee, and is said to have security for her own protection, people close to her said: “She is waking up to a different life." https://t.co/HtqaD9rrV7
Apple released the first-ever iPhone in the U.S. on June 29, 2007. Here’s a look back at every iteration. https://t.co/DLgZ06EQyF

R. Kelly was sentenced to 30 years in prison Wednesday for racketeering and sex-abuse offenses. The singer had been convicted of using his entourage to recruit women and underage girls for sex. https://t.co/oeex4xTgh7

Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has driven up food prices around the world, but the situation is less grim in Asia. Rice, following bumper crops, has generally been cheaper this year. https://t.co/2mvijsjJ11
An FCC member asked Apple and Google to remove TikTok from their app stores, citing security risks https://t.co/e0Vuf6jn5R

President Biden met with the heads of Japan and South Korea—the first such gathering between the three countries’ leaders in nearly five years—and pledged deeper cooperation to counter North Korea’s weapons provocations https://t.co/ejV3Y86ExX
The U.S. Commerce Department added five Chinese companies to an export blacklist for allegedly helping Russia’s military https://t.co/BELkJCWuKQ
From @WSJopinion: Pinning the inflation tail on Joe Biden amounts to blaming him for war-induced shortages and the Fed’s mistiming. It is a bum rap, writes Alan S. Blinder. https://t.co/3Er8VeaftG
Apple released the first-ever iPhone in the U.S. on June 29, 2007. Here’s a look back at every iteration. https://t.co/XVO81Qntdt

Cassidy Hutchinson has faced a wave of online attacks from Trump’s supporters following her testimony before the Jan. 6 committee, and is said to have security for her own protection, people close to her said: “She is waking up to a different life." https://t.co/AC9jomfuFK

From @WSJopinion: The end of Roe v. Wade brings cheap shots against Clarence Thomas, writes @jasonrileywsj. His concurrence in Dobbs isn’t personal. It is a principled analysis of due-process jurisprudence. https://t.co/f8XBAPmtUc
An FCC member asked Apple and Google to remove TikTok from their app stores, citing security risks https://t.co/rIjw4p2U0g
A 34-year-old Colorado man was gored by a bull bison in Yellowstone National Park on Monday, the second bison attack at the park in recent weeks https://t.co/x4s7HcqEiA

Breaking: R. Kelly was sentenced to 30 years in prison for racketeering and sex-abuse offenses. The singer had been convicted of using his entourage to recruit women and underage girls for sex. https://t.co/WwMoKNnf9O

The death toll among migrants who were abandoned in a tractor trailer in San Antonio, Texas, rose to 51 Tuesday, with several others hospitalized in critical condition. Here's what we know: https://t.co/MiC133RgnX

Former Rudy Giuliani associate Lev Parnas was sentenced to 20 months in prison for his role in a campaign-finance scheme that illegally pumped foreign money into U.S. elections https://t.co/vJIkgC4eyT
Apple released the first-ever iPhone in the U.S. on June 29, 2007. Here’s a look back at every iteration. https://t.co/GiikgvubQa
The U.S. will make its biggest military expansion in Europe since the Cold War, including its first permanent troop presence in Poland https://t.co/WBK3913DT9
Tesla is closing one of its Silicon Valley offices and laying off about 200 people there as part of the electric vehicle maker’s plans to trim its head count amid rising costs https://t.co/2EpejURHgN
Unlike wheat and corn, rice has generally been cheaper this year than it was last year—a boon for many Asian countries https://t.co/yQ8yzvGLLi
Hedge fund Three Arrows Capital was ordered by a court to liquidate, becoming the latest cryptocurrency casualty https://t.co/xWAUbOFLH9

In response to last week’s Supreme Court ruling that struck down New York state’s concealed gun law, a gun permit bill negotiated by Gov. Kathy Hochul requiring in-person training and mental health background checks is expected to quickly become law https://t.co/8HObUkHPdY

From @WSJopinion: The GOP has a golden opportunity to become the party for parents, but it won’t be able to hold on to that title by simply saying so. It will need to prove it, writes @DeAngelisCorey. https://t.co/ddpqXYohMv
Some 89% of Ukrainians say it would be unacceptable to give up territory seized by Russia in a peace deal with Moscow, a new Wall Street Journal-NORC poll finds https://t.co/7Bziv7x9BP

The U.S. has banned new imports of Russian gold, the country's second-most valuable export after energy, as Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine continues into its fourth month #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/I181lBlePm https://t.co/VMBUnw7krz
